author: Tristan Kirk
title: 'Deeply disturbing' teenager raped schoolgirl before carving his name into her arm in Hampstead cemetery attack
text:
Friday 13 January 2017 06:50 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard Sex attack: the horrific ordeal took place in Hampstead Cemetery Google Streetview 
A teenager has been branded “self-absorbed” and “deeply disturbing” by a judge as he faces years behind bars for raping and trying to murder a 15-year-old girl in the historic Hampstead Cemetery. 
Miles Hughes was just 17 when stabbed the girl repeatedly with a Stanley knife, after carving his name into her arm. 
He had pinned the girl down on the ground, grabbed her round the neck and raped her, ignoring her pleas for him to stop. 
When police searched Hughes’ bedroom, they found a hand-drawn picture of a clown adorned with a Nazi Swastika and 666 - the number of the Devil. 
Hughes denied attempted murder and rape, but an Old Bailey jury yesterday found him guilty of both charges after 16 hours of deliberations. 
Judge John Bevan QC told Hughes he is “bound to receive a substantial sentence” next month, ordering psychiatric assessments of the teenager to judge how much of a danger he poses to the public. 
He said the clown drawing and a letter to the victim after he had been arrested “seemed to me to display a lack of real emotion and an absorbing self-interest which I find deeply disturbing. 
“I’m bound to say I will take some persuading he is not self-absorbed, jealous, and controlling to a degree that makes him dangerous.” 
Hughes was convicted first by the jury of attempted murder, having already admitted wounding with intent by stabbing the girl. 
Yesterday afternoon he tutted and shook his head while readjusting his shirt cuffs as the jury also found him guilty of rape. 
Hughes carried out the horrifying attack on July 9 last year in the cemetery in West Hampstead, which had graves belonging the dozens of war heroes as well as famous names including satirist Alan Coren and theatre impresario Charles Wyndham. 
The teenager talked about music with the girl before turning the conversation to serial killers and monsters, asking: “How would you react if I said I was going to kill you?” 
He started etching his name on her arm with a Stanley knife before pushing the girl to the ground and raping her. 
Hughes then stabbed the girl repeatedly in the neck and chest, only stopping when a passerby intervened. 
Hughes, who is now 18, later admitted he had smiled and laughed as he fled the scene, and told a friend he had enjoyed seeing the victim begging on her knees, the court heard. 
Hughes called 999 himself after the attack, and police then searched his home to find the clown picture and a second sketch of a person with the words: “Anger creates Monsters, Hatred gives them reason.” 
During the trial, Hughes claimed he had sex with the girl consensually and denied trying to kill her. 
“I intended to cause her really serious harm”, he admitted. 
Hughes, of Dynham Road, Camden, waved to the public gallery as he was led away to the cells.
